heading: big ol' quarter for big blue
subheading: in the age of money-losing net phenoms, staid ibm popped off a hefty us$2.3 billion fourth-quarter profit, topping the street's estimates. also: sun and excite earnings are right in line with wall street's best guess.
author: reuters
text: ibm on thursday reported better-than-expected earnings for the fourth quarter, paced by continued strong growth in services and software. the world's largest computer maker said net earnings rose to us$2.3 billion, or $2.47 a diluted share, from $2.1 billion, or $2.11 a share, a year earlier. wall street analysts had forecast profit of $2.45 a share on average, according to first call, which tracks estimates. sales grew 6 percent to $25.1 billion.while total sales rose, some analysts had expected even stronger revenue growth. total hardware sales fell 2 percent to $11.3 billion, services revenues jumped 20 percent to $7.1 billion, and software sales grew 9 percent to $4.1 billion, ibm (ibm) said."we showed particular strength in services and software -- two areas of critical importance as our customers increasingly embrace e-business and network computers," chairman louis gerstner said in a statement. he noted that almost 60 percent of ibm's gross profit comes from services and software.the increase in earnings came despite continued weakness in asia and latin america, continued weak prices for computer memory chips, and weakness in its sales of server computers that link together computer networks, the company said.sales in north america rose 8 percent to $11.3 billion in the quarter and 13 percent to $8.7 billion in europe, the middle east, and africa. but sales edged down 3 percent to $4.2 billion in the asia-pacific region and tumbled 22 percent to $929 million in latin america.- - -sun shines: sun microsystems (sunw) reported a sharp rise in second-quarter earnings, propelled by strong sales of its network servers and workstations, and announced a two-for-one stock split.the palo alto, california, company reported net income of $261.1 million, or 64 cents a share, for its second fiscal quarter, up from $149.4 million, or 38 cents a share a year ago. excluding charges, sun earned $272.3 million, or 67 cents a share, just above the wall street forecast of 66 cents, according to first call corp.sun said revenues rose to $2.78 billion from $2.45 billion during the second quarter, ended 27 december. it took charges totaling $12 million related to acquisitions of beduin communications and i-planet."we continue to position sun to take advantage of the growing importance of web-centric computing," sun chief financial officer michael lehman said. "our focus on both the traditional enterprise customers, as well as the emerging growth of service providers, is enabling sun to realize more benefits from our vision of network computing."last quarter, even though sun's order growth rate was better than expected, the company warned wall street analysts not to raise earnings estimates for the second quarter, due to a switch to new software in its computer-systems unit.ahead of the announcement, sun's shares fell $7.13 to $98.25 in nasdaq trading.- - -post at home ho-hum: excite (xcit), fresh off the news that it is being acquired by at home (athm), on thursday reported a fourth-quarter profit that was in line with most forecasts and said sales and traffic to its sites rose sharply.the company earned $2.6 million, 4 cents per share, on a pro forma basis, compared with a pro forma loss in the year-ago quarter of $8.7 million, or 26 cents per share.fourth-quarter sales totaled $54.1 million, up from $20.5 million in the year-ago quarter, and traffic on the excite network of online properties reached an average 58 million pageviews per day at the end of december, up 15 percent from september.
